FlowchartMsg_USen_szs\OutroTips.msbt
OutroTips000_Title	Should I exercise if I feel sore?
OutroTips000_Caption	Don't overdo it. Take breaks!
OutroTips000	If you feel muscle pain, don't push it—take a break\nfrom training. Your results won't disappear over a\nshort rest, so take it easy until your symptoms disappear.\n\nPlease consult with your doctor if soreness does not\nstop after a reasonable time.
OutroTips001_Title	What are the basic types of exercise?
OutroTips001_Caption	Aerobic, strength, balance, and flexibility!
OutroTips001	Aerobic exercise increases your heart and respiratory rates, which\ncan help improve your overall fitness.\n*  Examples: Running, swimming\nStrength training works your muscles and can help make them stronger. \n*  Examples: Weight lifting, resistance exercises\nBalance exercises can help you avoid falls.\n*  Examples: Tai chi, certain yoga poses\nFlexibility exercises can help you stay limber.\n*  Examples: Yoga, stretching
OutroTips002_Title	Should I do the exercises in a certain order?
OutroTips002_Caption	You may want to start with the lower body!
OutroTips002	Most can do the exercises in any order, but you might find\nit's easier to start with your lower body. Many consider the\nlower-body exercises to be more strenuous, so you may want\nto start with those, then move on to upper-body exercises if\nyou find yourself becoming tired before finishing\nyour workout. Just make sure not to overdo it!\n\nPlease consult with your doctor if you are having difficulty\nwith certain exercises.
OutroTips003_Title	I'm worried that I'll get too muscular.
OutroTips003_Caption	It won't happen accidentally.
OutroTips003	You want to tone up your body, but you're not interested in a\nbodybuilder physique—does that describe you? If so, you can\nrest easy. Standard weight training with a light load won't result\nin bulging muscles easily. Bodybuilders' bodies are the result of\nvery hard training combined with careful management by\nprofessionals over a long period of time.
OutroTips005_Title	Should I do the exercises in a certain order?
OutroTips005_Caption	You may want to start with the lower body!
OutroTips005	Most can do the exercises in any order, but you might find\nit's easier to start with your lower body. Many consider the\nlower-body exercises to be more strenuous, so you may want\nto start with those, then move on to upper-body exercises if\nyou find yourself becoming tired before finishing\nyour workout. Just make sure not to overdo it!\n\nPlease consult with your doctor if you are having difficulty\nwith certain exercises.
OutroTips006_Title	I can't move the way the examples show me!
OutroTips006_Caption	Listen to your body!
OutroTips006	Sometimes you can't quite train in the exact way the examples\ndemonstrate—it can be hard to keep your balance or hold a\npose, for example. Fitness ability is different for everyone,\nso it's natural that there are some things you might not be able\nto do. Just exercise within the range of your ability, and don't\noverexert yourself.\n\nPlease consult a doctor if you have questions about any\nparticular exercise.
OutroTips007_Title	Is muscle training all about reps?
OutroTips007_Caption	Proper form is important too!
OutroTips007	In muscle training, muscle is gained according to the number\nof reps you perform. Reps are important for building muscle,\nbut so is proper form. And proper form can help you avoid\nmuscle strain and injuries. Too many reps, and your form\ncan suffer. So it's best to stay aware of your muscles, watch\nyour form, and perform the right movements to target your\nmuscles properly. But don't overexert yourself! It's a good idea\nto take a break if you feel tired or aren't focusing well.
OutroTips008_Title	At what time should I be training?
OutroTips008_Caption	Any time that's easy to stick to!
OutroTips008	There are a few theories about when the most effective time\nto train is, but the important thing is to turn your training into\na habit. Try to find the time of day that's easiest for you, but\nconsult a doctor if you have questions about a training plan\nthat's right for you.
OutroTips009_Title	Tell me about niacin!
OutroTips009_Caption	It's used throughout your body!
OutroTips009	Niacin (also called vitamin B3), may help support skin and\nnerves. It also aids in digestion and the conversion of\nfood to energy.\n\nIt's naturally found in milk, eggs, rice, fish, lean meats, legumes,\nand poultry, as well as various enriched breads and cereals.
OutroTips010_Title	What foods contain protein?
OutroTips010_Caption	Proteins can be found in a variety of foods!
OutroTips010	It is important to eat a variety of foods to give your body the\nnourishment it needs. Foods such as eggs, fish, dairy products\nsuch as cheese, and soybean products like tofu are all good\nsources of protein, but consult a doctor if you have questions\nabout your diet.
OutroTips011_Title	It's hard to get motivated when I don't feel an effect.
OutroTips011_Caption	Change up your training routine!
OutroTips011	If you're always doing the same training, your body will get\nused to the same movements, sometimes called a "plateau."\nWhen you reach this stage, it helps to change things up,\nlike increasing your reps or difficulty temporarily, to give \nyour body new stimulus. Or you could change what part \nof your body you're training. Mix up your daily training\nroutine to keep things interesting!
OutroTips012_Title	What are the "core muscles"?
OutroTips012_Caption	The muscles that support the core of your body!
OutroTips012	In this game, the core (or trunk) of the body refers to the torso,\nso the muscles in the torso are called "core muscles." This is\na collective term referring to a number of muscles in the chest,\nstomach, back, and buttocks. Strengthening your core muscles\ncan help improve posture, which may decrease lower-back and\nshoulder stiffness. Strengthening your core muscles may also\nhelp you move your body more easily during exercise.
OutroTips013_Title	Will squats make my legs look bigger?
OutroTips013_Caption	Probably not.
OutroTips013	Unless you're doing squats while holding heavy weights, your\nlegs won't get thicker easily. However, squats do use muscles\nin your legs and buttocks, so you may see some differences\nin the overall appearance of your lower body.
OutroTips014_Title	What can I do to keep fit?
OutroTips014_Caption	Lots of things!
OutroTips014	Exercise is good of course. Some other things to try include\ngetting adequate sleep, practicing deep breathing, adding\nshort stretch breaks throughout your day, going for walks,\nand even engaging in stress-relieving hobbies!\n\nA balanced eating plan, regular physical activity,\nand stress relief may help you to feel your best.
OutroTips015_Title	How can I eat more fruits and veggies?
OutroTips015_Caption	The following tips might help!
OutroTips015	Wondering how you can add more fruits and vegetables\ninto your diet?\n\n*  Try to include at least one vegetable in every meal.\n*  Shift your snacks toward fresh fruit and raw vegetables.\n*  Cycle through fruits and vegetables that are in season.\n*  Try some fruits and vegetables that you've never had before.
OutroTips016_Title	What is aerobic activity?
OutroTips016_Caption	Exercise that raises your heart rate!
OutroTips016	Aerobic activity uses large muscle groups (typically your\nchest, legs, and back) to increase your heart rate, which\nimproves your endurance and cardiovascular health.\nTry one of these activities or others you might enjoy:\n\n*  Brisk walking or jogging\n*  Swimming\n*  Bicycling (always wear a helmet!)\n*  Playing sports like basketball or soccer
OutroTips017_Title	What is a good exercise for me to try?
OutroTips017_Caption	It's up to you!
OutroTips017	It's better to mix different types of training into your regimen,\nbut if your goal is to build muscle, try squatting! Train with the\nproper form, and you can build up one of the largest\nmuscles in the body, the quadriceps (thighs), which help\nincrease your fitness. Squats train the glutes as well and \neven use the stomach and back muscles, so you can work \nquite a bit of your body. Squats can be a rewarding exercise,\nbut they're hard work, so don't overdo it!
OutroTips018_Title	What's so great about whole grains?
OutroTips018_Caption	Fiber and other nutrients!
OutroTips018	Whole grains (as opposed to refined grains) are seeds that\nare eaten with all the parts of the seed (including the bran,\nthe germ, and the endosperm). Despite their name, whole\ngrains also include grains that are ground into flour, as long\nas they were ground with all the parts of the seed!\n\nRefined grains have had the germ and bran removed, which\nalso removes much of the fiber content and other nutrients like\nB vitamins, iron, folate, selenium, potassium, and magnesium.
OutroTips019_Title	It's hard to get motivated when I don't feel an effect.
OutroTips019_Caption	Change up your training routine!
OutroTips019	If you're always doing the same training, your body will get\nused to the same movements, sometimes called a "plateau."\nWhen you reach this stage, it helps to change things up,\nlike increasing your reps or difficulty temporarily, to give \nyour body new stimulus. Or you could change what part \nof your body you're training. Mix up your daily training\nroutine to keep things interesting!
OutroTips020_Title	Tell me more about fruits and vegetables!
OutroTips020_Caption	They can provide many nutrients!
OutroTips020	You can get many essential vitamins and minerals from fruits\nand vegetables. However, some nutrients are rarer or harder\nto get from plant-based foods. These include protein, iron,\ncalcium, zinc, and vitamin B12. Make sure to eat a\nbalanced diet with a variety of foods, and consult your\ndoctor if you have questions about your diet.
OutroTips021_Title	I don't have time or energy to cook.
OutroTips021_Caption	Look for healthy convenience food!
OutroTips021	If you want to eat healthy, sometimes it's best if you buy and\nprepare the ingredients yourself. But it can be tough cooking\nevery day of the week, can't it? If you're not in the mood to\ncook, you could always buy a frozen or premade meal from\nthe supermarket. Just check the nutritional information to help\nyou choose foods that are nutritious and balanced.
OutroTips022_Title	Tell me about zinc!
OutroTips022_Caption	Your body uses zinc in lots of different ways!
OutroTips022	Zinc exists throughout the body and is used in cell division,\ncell growth, and healing. Zinc is also needed for the senses\nof smell and taste. \n\nAnimal proteins in general are good sources of zinc.\nOther sources include nuts, whole grains, legumes,\nand yeast.
OutroTips023_Title	What is BMI?
OutroTips023_Caption	It's a scale for comparing height/weight.
OutroTips023	BMI stands for Body Mass Index, which is a value calculated based on height and\nweight. BMI data is informational only and should not be considered a medical\ndiagnosis. For adults 21+, the calculation is "weight (kg) / (height (m) x height (m))."\nFor example, the BMI for a person 175 cm (5'9") tall who weighs 70 kg (154 lb.)\nwould be 70 / (1.75 x 1.75), approximately 22.86. However, BMI information may not\nbe as accurate for players with significant muscle mass or players under the age of\n20 whose bodies are not fully developed. According to WHO (World Health Organization)\nstandards, a typical adult BMI falls between 18.5 to 25. If you have questions\nabout potential weight issues regarding you or your child, please consult a doctor.
OutroTips024_Title	Should I be stretching until it hurts?
OutroTips024_Caption	No, don't stretch so far!
OutroTips024	You may have heard that pain means gain, but that's not\nalways true! If you overstretch and feel pain, your muscles could \nconstrict and tighten. The point of stretching is to loosen and\nrelax your muscles. So take it easy when stretching, and try\nto stretch within a comfortable range.
OutroTips025_Title	If you don't use your muscles, do they turn into fat?
OutroTips025_Caption	Nope!
OutroTips025	The idea that "unused muscle turns into fat" seems to be\na common misunderstanding. Muscle and fat, however, are\ncompletely different things, and muscle cannot turn into fat\n(or vice versa). If you don't use your muscles, they will simply\nget smaller. Losing muscle may lower your metabolism.\nThis phenomenon is probably where the misunderstanding\ncomes from.
OutroTips026_Title	I can eat as many vegetables as I want, right?
OutroTips026_Caption	Always eat foods in moderation.
OutroTips026	You can eat as many vegetables as you want because they're\nlow in calories...right? Turns out some veggies—like potatoes,\nsweet potatoes, corn, pumpkin, and tomatoes—have a higher\nsugar content than others. Vegetables that are rich in fiber,\nsuch as spinach, cabbage, lettuce, and other leafy greens\nmay be healthier choices.
OutroTips027_Title	Tell me about vitamin B12!
OutroTips027_Caption	It may help the brain and nervous system!
OutroTips027	Vitamin B12 is similar to the other B vitamins and helps your\nbody use protein. Vitamin B12 is also important to the\nproduction of red blood cells and the maintenance of\nyour central nervous system.\n\nAnimal proteins are the readiest sources of B12, especially\norgan meats and shellfish. Plant-based foods generally have\nto be fortified with it to be useful sources of B12.
OutroTips028_Title	Tell me about magnesium!
OutroTips028_Caption	The body needs it for a number of reasons.
OutroTips028	Magnesium is required for many different chemical reactions in\nthe body, from nerve and brain functions to immune support.\n\nIt's found primarily in vegetables, especially the dark green,\nleafy types. It can also be found in some fruits, nuts, legumes,\nsoy products, whole grains, and milk.
OutroTips029_Title	Can I have snacks?
OutroTips029_Caption	Sure, but in moderation!
OutroTips029	Snacks can act as an energy boost between meals, but some\nsnacks are healthier than others. Just check the nutritional\ninformation to help you choose snacks that are nutritious\nand balanced, but consult a doctor if you have questions\nabout your diet.
OutroTips030_Title	What are some whole grains?
OutroTips030_Caption	There's a bunch!
OutroTips030	There are probably more edible grains than you realize,\nso if you're looking for some variety, here are some of\nthe options available: amaranth, barley, buckwheat,\nbulgur, oats, quinoa, rice, rye, sorghum, spelt, teff,\nwheat, and wild rice.\n\nThey each have a different flavor, so give them a try!
OutroTips031_Title	How can I maintain a healthy lifestyle?
OutroTips031_Caption	Try to stay active!
OutroTips031	To help keep yourself fit, follow these guidelines:\n*  Eat a balanced diet\n*  Drink plenty of water\n*  Keep moving—use the stairs, take walking breaks, etc.\n*  Get plenty of sleep\n\nJust be mindful of your body's limitations and always exercise\nwithin your comfort range.
OutroTips032_Title	What actually IS a calorie?
OutroTips032_Caption	It's the energy contained in food.
OutroTips032	Strictly speaking, a "calorie" is a unit of energy, but the term\nis often used to refer to the energy itself contained in food.\nThe human body uses the energy (calories) absorbed from food\nin a number of different ways, such as regulating temperature,\nbuilding tissue, and operating muscles and internal organs.\nIn other words, it's the energy people need in order to live.
OutroTips033_Title	How can I eat more fruits and veggies?
OutroTips033_Caption	The following tips might help!
OutroTips033	Wondering how you can add more fruits and vegetables\ninto your diet?\n\n*  Try to include at least one vegetable in every meal.\n*  Shift your snacks toward fresh fruit and raw vegetables.\n*  Cycle through fruits and vegetables that are in season.\n*  Try some fruits and vegetables that you've never had before.
OutroTips034_Title	At what time should I be training?
OutroTips034_Caption	Any time that's easy to stick to!
OutroTips034	There are a few theories about when the most effective time\nto train is, but the important thing is to turn your training into\na habit. Try to find the time of day that's easiest for you, but\nconsult a doctor if you have questions about a training plan\nthat's right for you.
OutroTips035_Title	I'm worried that I'll get too muscular.
OutroTips035_Caption	It won't happen accidentally.
OutroTips035	You want to tone up your body, but you're not interested in a\nbodybuilder physique—does that describe you? If so, you can\nrest easy. Standard weight training with a light load won't result\nin bulging muscles easily. Bodybuilders' bodies are the result of\nvery hard training combined with careful management by\nprofessionals over a long period of time.
OutroTips036_Title	Tell me about vitamin A!
OutroTips036_Caption	Vitamin A may help to maintain teeth, bones, and vision.
OutroTips036	Vitamin A (also called retinol) may help maintain your teeth, bones,\nand various soft tissues. It may also support your vision.\n\nIt's found in cod-liver oil, eggs, fortified breakfast cereals,\nfortified skim milk, and orange and yellow fruits and vegetables.
OutroTips037_Title	Will squats make my legs look bigger?
OutroTips037_Caption	Probably not.
OutroTips037	Unless you're doing squats while holding heavy weights, your\nlegs won't get thicker easily. However, squats do use muscles\nin your legs and buttocks, so you may see some differences\nin the overall appearance of your lower body.
OutroTips038_Title	Is there benefit to muscle training for older people?
OutroTips038_Caption	Absolutely!
OutroTips038	Training can be appropriate for people of any age. \nWhether you're in your 60s, 70s, or beyond, \nolder people who do weight training may improve\ntheir overall health and stay more active. Just remember\nto exercise within the range of your ability, and don't\noverexert yourself. Consult a doctor if you have\nquestions about whether exercise is right for you.
OutroTips039_Title	What is reverse abdominal breathing?
OutroTips039_Caption	Pull in your belly when you inhale!
OutroTips039	When breathing abdominally, does your belly expand or\ndoes it contract? Normally it should expand as it fills with air.\nReverse abdominal breathing is consciously doing the opposite,\nand contracting your belly as you breathe in and expanding it\nwhen you breathe out. Try it out—surprisingly tricky, isn't it?
OutroTips040_Title	Should I exercise if I feel sore?
OutroTips040_Caption	Don't overdo it. Take breaks!
OutroTips040	If you feel muscle pain, don't push it—take a break\nfrom training. Your results won't disappear over a\nshort rest, so take it easy until your symptoms disappear.\n\nPlease consult with your doctor if soreness does not\nstop after a reasonable time.
OutroTips041_Title	What is aerobic activity?
OutroTips041_Caption	Exercise that raises your heart rate!
OutroTips041	Aerobic activity uses large muscle groups (typically your\nchest, legs, and back) to increase your heart rate, which\nimproves your endurance and cardiovascular health.\nTry one of these activities or others you might enjoy:\n\n*  Brisk walking or jogging\n*  Swimming\n*  Bicycling (always wear a helmet!)\n*  Playing sports like basketball or soccer
OutroTips042_Title	What can I do to keep fit?
OutroTips042_Caption	Lots of things!
OutroTips042	Exercise is good of course. Some other things to try include\ngetting adequate sleep, practicing deep breathing, adding\nshort stretch breaks throughout your day, going for walks,\nand even engaging in stress-relieving hobbies!\n\nA balanced eating plan, regular physical activity,\nand stress relief may help you to feel your best.
OutroTips043_Title	What should be my training target?
OutroTips043_Caption	Think about what you want to do.
OutroTips043	Are you setting vague goals, like "I want to be fitter"? That's fine,\nbut instead of focusing on "the way I want to be," why not\nidentify a specific activity you want to do? For example, if your\ngoal is to complete a 5K, you could focus on exercises to help\nwith your stamina. Having a defined goal can help you choose\nthe appropriate training for it.
OutroTips044_Title	Is it OK to train barefoot?
OutroTips044_Caption	It depends...
OutroTips044	Always make sure that you are training on a flat, nonslip\nsurface and that you have proper foot support for the\nexercises you're doing. Some people may be fine training\nbarefoot, but others may want to wear shoes. Check with\nyour doctor if you're not sure.
OutroTips045_Title	Why is sleep so important?
OutroTips045_Caption	It helps in an amazing number of ways!
OutroTips045	Regular, quality sleep gives your body and brain time to\nrecover from the day's activities. A good night's rest can\nhelp you feel more alert.\n\nMost adults need seven to eight hours of sleep per night.
OutroTips046_Title	Tell me about magnesium!
OutroTips046_Caption	The body needs it for a number of reasons.
OutroTips046	Magnesium is required for many different chemical reactions in\nthe body, from nerve and brain functions to immune support.\n\nIt's found primarily in vegetables, especially the dark green,\nleafy types. It can also be found in some fruits, nuts, legumes,\nsoy products, whole grains, and milk.
OutroTips047_Title	Tell me about sodium!
OutroTips047_Caption	It is an element that the body needs to work properly!
OutroTips047	Sodium is involved in your body's regulation of both blood\npressure and blood volume. It is also required for your nerves\nand muscles to work correctly.\n\nSodium is found naturally in most foods, and is also\nadded to most processed foods.
OutroTips048_Title	Tell me about iron!
OutroTips048_Caption	It is a mineral found throughout the body!
OutroTips048	Your body needs iron to make hemoglobin and myoglobin,\ntwo proteins that carry oxygen through the body. \nHemoglobin is found in your blood, and myoglobin\nis found in your muscles.\n\nGood sources of iron include dried beans, dried fruits, eggs,\nliver, lean red meat, oysters, dark-meat poultry, salmon, tuna,\nand whole grains.
OutroTips049_Title	Is it true that weight training is good for bones?
OutroTips049_Caption	Weight training could help strengthen your bones.
OutroTips049	It may surprise you, but bones and muscle can be built using the\nsame exercises. Bones also get benefits from exercise, so always\nmake sure you are using proper form and an appropriate amount\nof resistance. Try doing some squats to help strengthen bones\nand muscles. For those who find squats difficult, you can go up\nand down stairs instead. But consult a doctor if you have\nquestions about the type of training that's right for you.
OutroTips050_Title	Tell me about zinc!
OutroTips050_Caption	Your body uses zinc in lots of different ways!
OutroTips050	Zinc exists throughout the body and is used in cell division,\ncell growth, and healing. Zinc is also needed for the senses\nof smell and taste. \n\nAnimal proteins in general are good sources of zinc.\nOther sources include nuts, whole grains, legumes,\nand yeast.
OutroTips051_Title	Will I lose my training results if I take a break?
OutroTips051_Caption	Not necessarily!
OutroTips051	It takes a while of not using your muscles for them to go\nback to how they were before training. Small gaps in\ntraining are no problem at all. It depends on how you\ntrain, but muscles start to return to how they were\nafter more than 10 days of rest.
OutroTips052_Title	Tell me about fiber!
OutroTips052_Caption	It aids in digestion!
OutroTips052	Fiber helps your digestion by promoting the movement of\nmaterial through your digestive system.\n\nInsoluble fiber is found in wheat bran, vegetables, and whole\ngrains. Soluble fiber is found in oat bran, barley, nuts, seeds,\nbeans, lentils, peas, and some fruits and vegetables.
OutroTips053_Title	Tell me about riboflavin!
OutroTips053_Caption	It may help with growth and red-blood-cell production!
OutroTips053	Riboflavin (also called vitamin B2) works together with the other\nB vitamins. It may help with growth and red-blood-cell production,\nand, in addition, it may help your body use the proteins you eat.\n\nIt is found in dairy products, eggs, green leafy vegetables,\nlean meats, organ meats, legumes, milk, and nuts.
OutroTips054_Title	Tell me about thiamine!
OutroTips054_Caption	It helps you get energy from the food you eat!
OutroTips054	Thiamine (also called vitamin B1) may help turn carbohydrates\nyou eat into energy to power your body (especially the brain\nand nervous system). Thiamine may also help your muscles\ncontract and your nerves carry signals.\n\nIt's found in a lot of enriched and fortified products, but is\nnaturally occurring in whole grains, wheat germ, beef, pork,\nsome fish, eggs, legumes, nuts, and seeds.
OutroTips055_Title	Is it OK to train barefoot?
OutroTips055_Caption	It depends...
OutroTips055	Always make sure that you are training on a flat, nonslip\nsurface and that you have proper foot support for the \nexercises you're doing. Some people may be fine training\nbarefoot, but others may want to wear shoes. Check with\nyour doctor if you're not sure.
OutroTips056_Title	Should I train when my body feels bad?
OutroTips056_Caption	Please don't! Rest instead!
OutroTips056	You're devoted to your training and don't want to miss a day\nbecause you're not feeling well. We get that, but it is important\nto rest and take a break when you are not feeling your best.\nYou won't lose the results of your training if you take a break\nfor a while. Come back to training once you are feeling better\nand have recovered. Consult a doctor if you have questions\nabout whether you're well enough to exercise.
OutroTips057_Title	Tell me about niacin!
OutroTips057_Caption	It's used throughout your body!
OutroTips057	Niacin (also called vitamin B3), may help support skin and\nnerves. It also aids in digestion and the conversion of\nfood to energy.\n\nIt's naturally found in milk, eggs, rice, fish, lean meats, legumes,\nand poultry, as well as various enriched breads and cereals.
OutroTips058_Title	Tell me about folic acid!
OutroTips058_Caption	It may help tissues grow and cells work!
OutroTips058	Folic acid (also called folate or vitamin B9) may help tissues\ngrow, red blood cells form, and DNA get produced. It may also\nwork with vitamin B12 and vitamin C to help the body use,\ncreate, and break down proteins.\n\nIt occurs naturally in dark green leafy vegetables, dried\nlegumes, and citrus fruits. It is also often found in fortified\nbreads, cereals, pastas, and other enriched-grain products.
OutroTips059_Title	Tell me about vitamin B12!
OutroTips059_Caption	It may help the brain and nervous system!
OutroTips059	Vitamin B12 is similar to the other B vitamins and helps your\nbody use protein. Vitamin B12 is also important to the\nproduction of red blood cells and the maintenance of\nyour central nervous system.\n\nAnimal proteins are the readiest sources of B12, especially\norgan meats and shellfish. Plant-based foods generally have\nto be fortified with it to be useful sources of B12.
OutroTips060_Title	Does a low BMI mean I'm healthy?
OutroTips060_Caption	BMI data is informational only.
OutroTips060	According to WHO (World Health Organization) standards,\na typical adult BMI falls between 18.5 to 25. Keep in mind,\nhowever, that BMI information may not be as accurate for\nplayers with significant muscle mass or players under the age\nof 20 whose bodies are not yet fully developed. If you have\nquestions about potential weight issues regarding you or\nyour child, please consult a doctor.
OutroTips061_Title	Why is sleep so important?
OutroTips061_Caption	It helps in an amazing number of ways!
OutroTips061	Regular, quality sleep gives your body and brain time to\nrecover from the day's activities. A good night's rest can\nhelp you feel more alert.\n\nMost adults need seven to eight hours of sleep per night.
OutroTips062_Title	What does blood pressure represent?
OutroTips062_Caption	How hard your blood pushes on your arteries!
OutroTips062	Your blood-pressure reading consists of two numbers. The\nfirst number is the pressure when your heart beats and the\nblood is at maximum pressure. The second number is when\nyour heart is resting between beats and the blood is at\nminimum pressure. A normal blood-pressure reading for an\nadult is between 120/80 and 90/60.
OutroTips063_Title	What defines dynamic stretching?
OutroTips063_Caption	Stretches that move your body!
OutroTips063	When you think of stretching, you probably think of someone\nholding a particular pose for a long time, usually with an arm\nor leg in a strange position. That kind of stretching is called\nstatic stretching, because you hold yourself in stasis to do it.\nIn dynamic stretching, however, you keep moving your body\nthroughout the stretch. Dynamic stretching is best done before\ntraining as a warm-up to help prevent injuries. Always make sure\nyou use proper form and never stretch to the point of pain.
OutroTips064_Title	Is there any reason to stretch after exercising?
OutroTips064_Caption	To cool down your body!
OutroTips064	After training, you should use stretches to cool down.\nWe recommend static stretches that extend your muscles\nand hold them. These can help ease stiff muscles and regulate\nyour breathing. Always make sure you use proper form and\nnever stretch to the point of pain. In addition, stretching after\nexercise may prevent muscle soreness later. Please take some\ntime to stretch until your mind and body settle down, OK?
OutroTips065_Title	Tell me about fiber!
OutroTips065_Caption	It aids in digestion!
OutroTips065	Fiber helps your digestion by promoting the movement of\nmaterial through your digestive system.\n\nInsoluble fiber is found in wheat bran, vegetables, and whole\ngrains. Soluble fiber is found in oat bran, barley, nuts, seeds,\nbeans, lentils, peas, and some fruits and vegetables.
OutroTips066_Title	Tell me more about fruits and vegetables!
OutroTips066_Caption	They can provide many nutrients!
OutroTips066	You can get many essential vitamins and minerals from fruits\nand vegetables. However, some nutrients are rarer or harder\nto get from plant-based foods. These include protein, iron,\ncalcium, zinc, and vitamin B12. Make sure to eat a\nbalanced diet with a variety of foods, and consult your\ndoctor if you have questions about your diet.
OutroTips067_Title	Tell me about thiamine!
OutroTips067_Caption	It helps you get energy from the food you eat!
OutroTips067	Thiamine (also called vitamin B1) may help turn carbohydrates\nyou eat into energy to power your body (especially the brain\nand nervous system). Thiamine may also help your muscles\ncontract and your nerves carry signals.\n\nIt's found in a lot of enriched and fortified products, but is\nnaturally occurring in whole grains, wheat germ, beef, pork,\nsome fish, eggs, legumes, nuts, and seeds.
OutroTips068_Title	Is there benefit to muscle training for older people?
OutroTips068_Caption	Absolutely!
OutroTips068	Training can be appropriate for people of any age. \nWhether you're in your 60s, 70s, or beyond, \nolder people who do weight training may improve\ntheir overall health and stay more active. Just remember\nto exercise within the range of your ability, and don't\noverexert yourself. Consult a doctor if you have\nquestions about whether exercise is right for you.
OutroTips069_Title	What are the basic types of exercise?
OutroTips069_Caption	Aerobic, strength, balance, and flexibility!
OutroTips069	Aerobic exercise increases your heart and respiratory rates, which\ncan help improve your overall fitness.\n*  Examples: Running, swimming\nStrength training works your muscles and can help make them stronger. \n*  Examples: Weight lifting, resistance exercises\nBalance exercises can help you avoid falls.\n*  Examples: Tai chi, certain yoga poses\nFlexibility exercises can help you stay limber.\n*  Examples: Yoga, stretching
OutroTips070_Title	Should I train when my body feels bad?
OutroTips070_Caption	Please don't! Rest instead!
OutroTips070	You're devoted to your training and don't want to miss a day\nbecause you're not feeling well. We get that, but it is important\nto rest and take a break when you are not feeling your best.\nYou won't lose the results of your training if you take a break\nfor a while. Come back to training once you are feeling better\nand have recovered. Consult a doctor if you have questions\nabout whether you're well enough to exercise.
OutroTips071_Title	What defines dynamic stretching?
OutroTips071_Caption	Stretches that move your body!
OutroTips071	When you think of stretching, you probably think of someone\nholding a particular pose for a long time, usually with an arm\nor leg in a strange position. That kind of stretching is called\nstatic stretching, because you hold yourself in stasis to do it.\nIn dynamic stretching, however, you keep moving your body\nthroughout the stretch. Dynamic stretching is best done before\ntraining as a warm-up to help prevent injuries. Always make sure\nyou use proper form and never stretch to the point of pain.
OutroTips072_Title	Tell me about sodium!
OutroTips072_Caption	It is an element that the body needs to work properly!
OutroTips072	Sodium is involved in your body's regulation of both blood\npressure and blood volume. It is also required for your nerves\nand muscles to work correctly.\n\nSodium is found naturally in most foods, and is also\nadded to most processed foods.
OutroTips073_Title	What is reverse abdominal breathing?
OutroTips073_Caption	Pull in your belly when you inhale!
OutroTips073	When breathing abdominally, does your belly expand or\ndoes it contract? Normally it should expand as it fills with air.\nReverse abdominal breathing is consciously doing the opposite,\nand contracting your belly as you breathe in and expanding it\nwhen you breathe out. Try it out—surprisingly tricky, isn't it?
OutroTips074_Title	I will absolutely train every day!
OutroTips074_Caption	Make sure not to overdo it!
OutroTips074	It's good to make exercising a habit, but making it a \nhard-and-fast rule to train absolutely every day might\nbe discouraging. Your results won't vanish even after\nseveral days, so you can miss a day here and there.\nWhat's important isn't training without fail but focusing\non your overall well-being.
OutroTips075_Title	Can I tone my thighs with just squats?
OutroTips075_Caption	It's best to mix it up with other training!
OutroTips075	Squats are an efficient method of training, but no single exercise\ncan be a balanced regimen by itself. It's better to mix various\ndifferent types of training into your regimen. You can do\nbalanced training and tone your legs by mixing squats with\nother exercises to benefit your entire body. Consult a doctor\nif you have questions about the type of exercises that are\nright for you.
OutroTips03	To finish up, here are some\npostexercise tips...
OutroTips04	Are you thinking, "What can I do\nto be healthy?"
OutroTips05	Eat a balanced diet...
OutroTips06	And exercise!

StretchDyn30	Keep your posture straight.
StretchDyn36	Alternate bringing your knees up to touch the Ring-Con!
StretchDyn37	Make sure your back is straight.
StretchDyn38	Be mindful of your body, and stretch within the range of your ability.
StretchDyn39	This stretch targets the area between the thighs and glutes.
StretchDyn40	Breathe out as you raise your knees.
StretchDyn41	Try to raise your knees upward rather than out.
StretchDyn42b	Be careful not to hit the Ring-Con against the leg strap.
StretchDyn43	Next is the heel lift stretch.
StretchDyn44	Bring the insides of your ankles up toward the Ring-Con!
StretchDyn45	Focus on moving the insides of your ankles upward.
StretchDyn46	This stretch can help make your hips more flexible.
StretchDyn47	Breathe out as you raise your ankles.
StretchDyn48	Be mindful of your body, and stretch within the range of your ability.
StretchDyn49	Focus on keeping your knees out.
StretchDyn50	This stretch targets your lower back.
StretchDyn51	Next is the back straightening stretch.
StretchDyn52	Take a big step forward and drop your hips.
StretchDyn53	Don't let your knees move too far forward.
StretchDyn54	Focus on lowering your body without putting too much weight on your front foot.
StretchDyn55	Breathe in as you extend your leg. Breathe out as you pull it back.
StretchDyn56	Focus on your form when raising your arms.
StretchDyn57	Make sure your toes are pointed straight ahead of you.
StretchDyn58	Be sure to keep your lower back straight.
StretchDyn59	You should be able to feel your back muscles stretching.
StretchDyn60	This stretch works your core as well.
StretchDyn61	Finally, spread your feet.
StretchDyn62	Raise the Ring-Con above your head, and lean to the side.
StretchDyn64	Be sure to keep your lower back straight.
StretchDyn63	Focus on leaning to the side without bending forward.
StretchDyn66	As you exhale, begin to lean.
StretchDyn67	This should stretch both the muscles in your sides and in your arms.
StretchDyn68	Try not to bounce during this stretch.
StretchDyn69	This stretch works your back.
StretchDyn100	Great job!
StretchDyn101	Let's do one more of each!
StretchDyn103	Face forward without letting your head drop.
StretchDyn108	As you get comfortable doing this stretch, make sure you're still making large movements.
StretchDyn110	Let's begin with dynamic stretching.
StretchDyn111	Try to mirror Tipp's movements without overextending yourself.
StretchDyn112	All right! Music, start!
StretchDyn116	Last time!
Attention	Move to the extent that you can without overexerting yourself.
FlowchartMsg_USen_szs\StretchStatic.msbt
StretchSta30	Let's begin our static stretching. You won't need the Ring-Con.
StretchSta31	Be mindful of your body, and stretch within the range of your ability.
StretchSta36	And your stretching is complete. Good job!
StretchSta100	Bring yourself back slowly.
StretchSta101	Now do the same on the opposite side.
StretchSta102	Hold it like that for a little longer.
StretchSta103	Breathe slowly as you hold.
StretchSta37	Raise both arms, and pull down on your left elbow.
StretchSta38	Stretch your upper arms while pulling your elbow downward.
StretchSta40	Stretch slowly and don't hold your breath.
StretchSta41	Be careful not to let your head fall forward.
StretchSta42	Be careful not to let your upper body tilt to the side.
StretchSta43	Bend your left knee, and bring your ankle up behind you.
StretchSta44	Pull your knee backward, and stretch the front of your thigh.
StretchSta45	You can use a wall or chair for balance if you need to.
StretchSta46	Hold the top of your foot to stretch your shin muscles as well.
StretchSta47	Be careful not to bend your lower back backward.
StretchSta48	Spread your feet, raise both hands, and hold your left wrist.
StretchSta49	While pulling on your wrist, tilt to the right and stretch your side.
StretchSta50	Return to your original position, switch hands, and bend the other way.
StretchSta51	Stretch slowly—don't overdo it.
StretchSta52	Tilt directly to the side while taking care not to slouch.
StretchSta53	Don't hold your breath!
StretchSta54	Put your right leg forward, and put your hands on your hips.
StretchSta55	Bend your right knee and stretch out your left calf.
StretchSta56	Now switch legs.
StretchSta57	Shift your center of balance forward,\nand stretch out the opposite side.
StretchSta58	Stretch slowly, and do your best not to bounce.
StretchSta59	If you're less flexible, it's OK if your heel goes off the ground.
StretchSta60	Bring your feet together and loosen up.
StretchSta61	Bend your body forward to stretch your lower back and the backs of your thighs.
StretchSta62	Bend forward while breathing out. Once you come to a stop, breathe in slowly.
StretchSta63	Bend your knees slightly, and raise your body bit by bit from your lower back until you're upright.
StretchSta64	Join your hands together in front of you.
StretchSta65	With your palms facing out, stretch out your back.
StretchSta66	Position your glutes as if you're going to sit down, then stretch your hands forward.
StretchSta67	Put your right foot forward and cross your legs.
StretchSta68	Bend your body forward, and stretch the back of your left leg.
StretchSta69	Straighten up and switch legs.
StretchSta70	Stretch the opposite side as well.
StretchSta71	Start bringing your fingertips close to your back leg.
StretchSta97	Slowly straighten up, bit by bit, starting from your lower back.
StretchSta72	Stretch your left arm to the side, and hold it with your right arm.

LayoutMsg_USen_szs\MovieGuide00.msbt
T_Guide_N_14	Please make sure you have the Ring-Con accessory,\nleg strap, and left and right Joy-Con ready.
T_Title_00	Preparing the Leg Strap
T_Guide_N_16	Make sure you have a clear view of\nthe screen so you can see the instructions.
T_Guide_N_01	Push the left Joy-Con firmly into the\npocket on the leg strap.
T_Guide_N_02	Sit down in a chair.
T_Guide_N_03	Place the leg strap high on your left leg,\nabove the center of your thigh.
T_Guide_N_04	Make sure not to let it slip.
T_Guide_N_05	Now, wrap the leg strap around your thigh.
T_Guide_N_06	Put the tip of the strap through the hole.
T_Guide_N_07	Tighten the leg strap by pulling to the right side.\nWhile still pulling, fasten the tip.
T_Guide_N_08	The leg strap is now attached!
T_Guide_N_09	If the leg strap comes loose,\nplease tighten it again.
T_Guide_N_15	Check that the leg strap is firmly fastened over\nthe center of your left thigh, but not too tight!
T_Title_01	Preparing the Ring-Con
T_Guide_N_11	Attach the right Joy-Con by sliding it\ninto the Ring-Con.
T_Guide_N_12	Slide until you hear a clicking noise.
T_Guide_N_13	You have assembled the Ring-Con!

LayoutMsg_USen_szs\TitleExplainStandAlone00.msbt
T_Title_00	Multitask Mode
T_Explain_00	In this mode, you can work out using only the Ring-Con without\nthe need for a screen.
T_Explain_01	Enabling \x0e\0\x03\x02\x01\0Multitask Mode\x0e\0\x03\x02ÿÿ records the \x0e\0\x03\x02\x01\0number of presses and pulls\x0e\0\x03\x02ÿÿ you\ndo with the Ring-Con while you watch television or do other activities.
T_Explain_02	To enable \x0e\0\x03\x02\x01\0Multitask Mode\x0e\0\x03\x02ÿÿ, first set the Nintendo Switch system\nto sleep mode or turn it off. After that, attach the Joy-Con (R) to\nthe Ring-Con and press the \x0e\0\x03\x02\x01\0Right Stick\x0e\0\x03\x02ÿÿ as shown in the diagram.
T_Explain_03	While \x0e\0\x03\x02\x01\0Multitask Mode\x0e\0\x03\x02ÿÿ is enabled, up to \x0e\0\x03\x02\x01\0500 reps\x0e\0\x03\x02ÿÿ of presses and pulls\nyou do will be recorded. When you return here afterward, you'll get a\nbonus in \x0e\0\x03\x02\x01\0Adventure\x0e\0\x03\x02ÿÿ mode according to how many presses you did.\n(This bonus is available once per player per day.)
T_OperationBoot_00	Press
T_Note_00	OFF
T_Explain_04	If you're connected to the Internet, you can \x0e\0\x03\x02\x01\0send the extra press/pull\ncounts\x0e\0\x03\x02ÿÿ you've earned in Multitask Mode to your \x0e\0\x03\x02\x01\0friends\x0e\0\x03\x02ÿÿ as a \x0e\0\x03\x02\x01\0present\x0e\0\x03\x02ÿÿ.\n(Only once per friend per day!)

CommonTips_34	Keep the center of your body from wobbling.
CommonTips_35	Hold the Ring-Con up straight!
CommonTips_36	Focus on your chest, not just your hands, and press in!
CommonTips_37	Press in away from your body to increase difficulty.
CommonTips_38	If it's too hard, bring the Ring-Con closer to your body.

CommonTips_40	Don't just press in with your arms!
CommonTips_41	Keep your legs straight!
CommonTips_42	Focus on the engaged muscles.

CommonTips_47	Keep your back straight!
